awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Political Science: Reform of China's Household Registration System
awd_abstract_narration:
This award satisfies Division B, Title V, Sec. 543 of the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act of 2013 (P.L. 113-6, enacted on March 26, 2013). 

The project asks the question: given the challenges to providing social welfare, why do some non-democratic local governments expand welfare provision while others do not? The project will examine how incentives for national and international economic competitiveness interact with local political conditions and the resulting impact on social welfare in the world's largest non-democracy. The research addresses issues that affect domestic policy-making and the foundations of political stability in China.

Access to social welfare in China is dependent on household registration status. For the last fifty years, the household registration system has divided every city's population into two classes: those with access and those without. The national government began a national campaign in 2003 to make the system more equitable, but some local governments, which fund social welfare, resisted. Local governments prefer not to distribute welfare to a greater number of the urban population because this allows them to keep wages low and maintain China's comparative labor advantage. Competition across Chinese localities for economic investment leads to expansion in social welfare, potentially increasing wages and urban-rural integration for China's lowest paid workers. 

Reforms to China's welfare system may dramatically reduce China's low-wage labor pool, increasing the costs of production, thereby increasing the cost of China's cheap exports. This impacts U.S. economic interests in two ways. First, the reforms could increase the costs of China's exports, greatly increasing costs to China's trading partners. Second, reforms aim to increase China's competitiveness for investment, suggesting a new and changing environment for American investors. Better understanding China's domestic politics is important for US security interests as well. Only in-depth, informed fieldwork will illuminate the true consequences of reforms for China's global competitiveness. The research design combines qualitative case studies with statistical analysis of an original, large-N dataset of all China's municipalities.

The project's intellectual merit is linked to three critical areas. First, it expands understanding of social welfare regimes by exploring a new welfare regime in an authoritarian setting. Globally, social welfare states are under pressure to limit welfare benefits so as to advance economic interests; this is even more likely in developing, authoritarian settings. Second, this research will enhance understanding of the relationship between labor market manipulation and social welfare. Finally, this research will expand understanding of the meaning of citizenship and the rights of citizens in an important developing, authoritarian country. 

The broader impacts include several contributions. Findings from this research will be presented at conferences, data collected will be made publicly available, and two graduate research assistants with specialization in legal studies will be trained in qualitative data collection.

por.por_cntn:
While China's economic growth and industrial production has gained significant political and scholarly attention, less is known about the political and social institutions underpinning the growth. China's household registration system, or hukou, informally restricts migration; locks a significant proportion of the population out of state provided welfare; and artificially depresses wages, allowing the industrial sector to maintain its labor dependent comparative advantage. For the last fifty years, the household registration system has divided every city's population along two lines: rural/urban and local/non-local; only local urban citizens are eligible for social welfare benefits, including pensions, public health insurance, access to public schools, and college entrance exams. Those with rural or non-local hukou have not enjoyed these benefits. Central government leaders began pushing for reform in 2003 with a renewed, more aggressive campaign in the fall of 2014, but local governments, the implementers of reform, use the system to limit their obligations to provide social services and in most cases resist reform. Should full reform succeed, with the dissolution of the household registration system, wages and local government fiscal burdens would rise, leading to more expensive exports and rising public debt. Should full reform fail, the current caste-like system of fully incorporated local urban residents receiving privileged access and internal migrants and rural populations remaining second class citizens in their own country with increasing likelihood of social tension and popular unrest.

This project represents a unique, disaggregated attempt to understand reform, local variation, as well as demand for reform at the lowest levels. Specifically, researchers evaluated the significant variation in policy reform pursued by local governments, analyzing (1) whether or not policy reform deconstructed the household registration system or adapted it without formally reforming the inherent structures, (2) the consequences for these reforms on access to social welfare, and (3) the ways in which these reforms are presented and advertised to the public. Additionally, this project included a pilot for an innovative general population survey targeting all populations without local urban registration to measure demand for reform.

The researchers designed a standardized, comprehensive scale to rate the form and depths of hukou policy reform providing information essential for both academic and policy related questions based on the ease of population mobility, manipulations of the labor market, and access to social welfare for individuals registered inside and outside of a specific location. This instrument was combined with a comprehensive dataset on China's 333 municipalities which includes data on municipalities' government finance; economic indicators and economic structure variables; social policy outcomes, such as health and education service providers; population, including urban and rural population divisions; and the distribution of social welfare geographically. In order to contextualize the quantitative dataset, researchers conducted over forty interviews with policy makers and policy implementors to understand how current regulations came about and how officials see reform in practice.
